qas.question: To what language group does Old English belong?
Along with Old Saxon, what language is closely related to Old English?
To what modern language is Old English similar?
In what century did the Latin alphabet replace the runic system in Old English writing?
What other Germanic languages are close to modern English?
What is modern German very different from?

plausible_answers.text: a version of the Latin alphabet

qas.question: What replaced runic writing in the 900's

context: Old English is one of the <a0_0>West Germanic<a0_0/> languages, and its closest relatives are <a1_0><b4_0>Old Frisian<a1_0/> and Old Saxon<b4_0/>. Like other <b5_0>old Germanic languages<b5_0/>, it is very different from Modern English and difficult for Modern English speakers to understand without study. Old English grammar is quite similar to that of modern <a2_0>German<a2_0/>: nouns, adjectives, pronouns, and verbs have many inflectional endings and forms, and word order is much freer. The oldest Old English inscriptions were written using a runic system, but from about the <a3_0>9th<a3_0/> century this was replaced by <b6_0>a version of the Latin alphabet<b6_0/>.
